objtitle.title: *The Miracle of the Loaves and Fishes*

objinfo.medium: water-based tempera with a glue and/or gum binder and with pen and ink outlining

provenance.name: Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold from his collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 140, with *The Circumcision*, Butlin 403 (16s. to "C. Martin," probably a dealer); anonymous owner or owners between 1853 and the 1960s; "bought c. 1960 at a London sale room (not Christie's or Sotheby's) in a mixed lot as 'and another [item]'" (Butlin 416); sold Sotheby's, 23 Nov. 1966, lot 82 (£1000 to A. J. Mathers acting for Kerrison Preston); sold from Preston's estate, Sotheby's, 20 March 1974, lot 28 (£2000 to the dealer Herner Wengraf Ltd.); "passed by amalgamation" (Butlin 416) to the dealer P. and D. Colnaghi; passed to the dealer Rafael Valls Gallery; offered Christie's, 23 June 1978, lot 145 (not sold); acquired April 1980 from Rafael Valls Gallery by Robert N. Essick.

repository.institution: Collection of Robert N. Essick, Altadena, California

desc.objtitle: The Miracle of the Loaves and Fishes, Object 1 (Butlin 416)

objnote.p: Blake exhibited this work at the Royal Academy in 1800. The painting has been restored at least twice. The faces of the three Apostles left of Christ have been overpainted in ways uncharacteristic of Blake's work.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design represents Christ's miracle of the loaves and fishes as described in Matthew 14:15-21. In the center stands Jesus, with long hair, a beard, and a halo (the halo no much decayed). He faces forward and wears a gown. His arms are bent at the elbow with his right palm facing out, as though blessing, and his left arm is holding what appears to be two loaves of bread. Three of the Evangelists, probably Matthew, Mark, and Luke, stand on the left. The leftmost of this group faces left and is bending down slightly to look at the man to whom he hands bread. He has short, curly hair and a beard, and wears a gown. In his left arm, which is bent, he holds what appear to be three loaves of bread. His right arm is at his side, and he uses that hand to give out another loaf. The middle of the apostles to the left of Jesus faces forward. He has curly hair and a beard and wears a gown. His eyes appear to be closed or cast sharply down. In his arms, which are crossed, he appears to hold two loaves of bread and a fish. The rightmost of the apostles to the left of Jesus faces right and slightly forward. He has a beard and wears a gown, and appears to be looking at Jesus. At least his left hand is raised, palm out. The largest figure right of Jesus and just within the right margin is probably John, the youngest Evangelist. He faces right, though with his head turned slightly forward. He bends forward to hand food to someone past the edge of the image. He wears a gown and has long, possibly curly hair. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent slightly. He holds with is left hand a cloth, or a part of his gown, which may contain a loaf of bread visible just left of his right upper arm. The suggestion of the multitudes gathered to hear Jesus preach and to be fed by him is made by a number of groups of figures, most of which are indistinct. There are two groups of huddled figures to the left of the leftmost disciple, one in the background and one in the foreground. The group in the background is particularly indistinct and could contain any numbers of bodies, but there is the suggestion of the back of at least one figure, sitting and facing right. In the group in the foreground, two figures are distinguishable, male(?) child facing forward and an old man with a beard. The old man is seated, probably gowned, ans with his left arm bent upward to receive a loaf of bread from the apostle to the right. Between Jesus and the apostle to his right are two groups of huddled figures, one in the background and one in the middle ground. There may be ten or more figures in the group in the background. Two figures of indeterminate gender are somewhat distinguishable in the center of this group. The figure to the left sits, facing left, with its legs extended in front of it. Its left arm may be resting on its left thigh, and bent upward. The figure to the right lies, propped up on its right arm, which is bent at the elbow. It faces right and extends its legs in front of it. In the group in the middle ground, three heads are visible on the left side of the group. Their gender is indeterminable and they face right and forward. Directly below them is visible the head of what may be an old man in a gown, with long hair and a beard, facing right. On the right side of this group, two figures are distinguishable. The figure to the left may be a woman in a gown, facing left. The figure to the right is an old man in a gown, with long hair and a beard, facing left. His visible left arm is bent toward his chest, as though his arms are crossed. His right leg is extended backward, and both his legs are bent as though he is walking to the left. Given the similarity of his pose to that of the disciples in the foreground, he may be a disciple handing out food. In the foreground right of Christ, a nude young male with short, curly hair is seen from behind. He looks up to his left at Jesus. His left leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe. His arms are bent with the palms held vertically and out and the fingers spread. His size suggests that he is a child. In the crook of his right arm he holds a wicker basket. Above John, the Evangelist far right, are two groups of huddled figures, one atop a hill in the background and one midway down the hill. There may be seven or more figures in the group atop the hill. The only one clearly distinguishable sits, facing left, with its legs extended in front and bent slightly. There may be four or more figures in the group midway up the hill. The face of the leftmost figure is visible, facing right and slightly forward. There may be a group of huddled figures just above John's right lower arm. Three figures are distinguishable below and to the right of John. The leftmost figure is that of a nude child with short hair. This child faces right and slightly forward, and has its right arm bent upward to hold what appears to be a loaf of bread. Its left leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe, and both legs are bent to suggest that he(?) is walking to the right. The middle figure is that of a nude infant with short hair, being suckled. It faces right, with its head turned forward and its right arm bent upward to hold its mother's breast. The rightmost figure is that of a woman, with long, curly hair pulled up into a bun. Her breasts are exposed, but she may wear a skirt or have some other kind of cloth secured around her waist. She is sitting, facing left and forward, with her legs bent and drawn up slightly. Her arms are bent so that she can support with both hands the infant she is feeding. She may be looking at the child to the left who is carrying a loaf of bread. The foreground beneath Jesus and the apostles is grassy, as is the top of a hill in the background, far upper right. The sky appears to be cloudy.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center stands Jesus, with long hair, a beard, and a halo (the halo no much decayed). He faces forward and wears a gown. His arms are bent at the elbow with his right palm facing out, as though blessing, and his left arm is holding what appears to be two loaves of bread.

Three of the Evangelists, probably Matthew, Mark, and Luke, stand on the left. The leftmost of this group faces left and is bending down slightly to look at the man to whom he hands bread. He has short, curly hair and a beard, and wears a gown. In his left arm, which is bent, he holds what appear to be three loaves of bread. His right arm is at his side, and he uses that hand to give out another loaf. The middle of the apostles to the left of Jesus faces forward. He has curly hair and a beard and wears a gown. His eyes appear to be closed or cast sharply down. In his arms, which are crossed, he appears to hold two loaves of bread and a fish, the latter identifiable by its tail. The rightmost of the apostles to the left of Jesus faces right and slightly forward. He has a beard and wears a gown, and appears to be looking at Jesus. At least his left hand is raised, palm out.

The largest figure right of Jesus and just within the right margin is probably John, the youngest Evangelist. He faces right, though with his head turned slightly forward. He bends forward to hand food to someone past the edge of the image. He wears a gown and has long, possibly curly hair. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent slightly. He holds with is left hand a cloth, or a part of his gown, which may contain a loaf of bread visible just left of his right upper arm.

There are two groups of figures to the left of the leftmost disciple, one in the background and one in the foreground. The group in the background is particularly indistinct and could contain any numbers of bodies, but there is the suggestion of the back of at least one figure, sitting and facing right.

The suggestion of the multitudes gathered to hear Jesus preach and to be fed by him is made by a number of groups of figures, most of which are indistinct. There are two groups to the left of the leftmost disciple, one in the background and one in the foreground. The group in the background is particularly indistinct and could contain any numbers of bodies, but there is the suggestion of the back of at least one figure, sitting and facing right. In the group in the foreground, two figures are distinguishable, male(?) child facing forward and an old man with a beard. The old man is seated, probably gowned, ans with his left arm bent upward to receive a loaf of bread from the apostle to the right.

Between Jesus and the apostle to the right are two groups of huddled figures, one in the background and one in the middle ground. There may be ten or more figures in the group in the background. Two figures of indeterminate gender are somewhat distinguishable in the center of this group. The figure to the left sits, facing left, with its legs extended in front of it. Its left arm may be resting on its left thigh, and bent upward. The figure to the right lies, propped up on its right arm, which is bent at the elbow. It faces right and extends its legs in front of it.

Between Jesus and the apostle to his right are two groups of huddled figures, one in the background and one in the middle ground. In the group in the middle ground, three heads are visible to the left side of the group. Their gender is indeterminable and they face right and forward. Directly below them is visible the head of what may be an old man in a gown, with long hair and a beard, facing right. On the right side of this group, two figures are distinguishable. The figure to the left may be a woman in a gown, facing left. The figure to the right is an old man in a gown, with long hair and a beard, facing left. His visible left arm is bent toward his chest, as though his arms are crossed. His right leg is extended backward, and both his legs are bent as though he is walking to the left. Given the similarity of his pose to that of the disciples in the foreground, he may be a disciple handing out food.

Between Jesus and the apostle to the right is a nude male with short, curly hair is seen from behind. He looks up to his left at Jesus. His left leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe. His arms are bent with the palms held vertically and out and the fingers spread. His size suggests that he is a child. In the crook of his right arm, he holds a wicker basket.

Above John, the apostle on the right, are two groups of huddled figures, one atop a hill in the background and one midway down the hill. There may be seven or more figures in the group atop the hill. The only one clearly distinguishable sits, facing left, with its legs extended in front and bent slightly. There may be four or more figures in the group midway up the hill. The face of the leftmost figure is visible, facing right and slightly forward.
There may be a group of huddled figures just above John's right lower arm.

Below and to the right of John (the Evangelist on the right) are a group of three figures. The leftmost figure is that of a nude child with short hair. This child faces right and slightly forward, and has its right arm bent upward to hold what appears to be a loaf of bread. Its left leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe, and both legs are bent to suggest that he(?) is walking to the right. The middle figure is that of a nude infant with short hair being suckled. It faces right, with its head turned forward and its right arm bent upward to hold its mother's breast. The rightmost figure is that of a woman, with long, curly hair pulled up into a bun. Her breasts are uncovered, but may wear a skirt or have some other kind of cloth secured around her waist. She is sitting, facing left and forward, with her legs bent and drawn up slightly. Her arms are bent so that she can support the infant she is breast feeding with both hands. She may be looking at the child to the left who is carrying a loaf of bread.
The foreground beneath Jesus and the apostles is grassy.
There may be grass atop the hill far upper right.
A hill with a steep cliff on its left side rises far upper right. To the left is another hill or distant mountain.
The sky appears to be cloudy.
